content:
Sure, here's how the variables can be categorized:

Categorical variables:

* age\_group
* education
* race
* sex
* income\_poverty
* marital\_status
* rent\_or\_own
* employment\_status
* hhs\_geo\_region
* census\_msa
* employment\_industry
* employment\_occupation

Binary variables:

* behavioral\_antiviral\_meds
* behavioral\_avoidance
* behavioral\_face\_mask
* behavioral\_wash\_hands
* behavioral\_large\_gatherings
* behavioral\_outside\_home
* behavioral\_touch\_face
* doctor\_recc\_h1n1
* doctor\_recc\_seasonal
* chronic\_med\_condition
* child\_under\_6\_months
* health\_worker
* health\_insurance

Other relevant categorization:

* h1n1\_concern: Ordinal variable
* h1n1\_knowledge: Ordinal variable
* opinion\_h1n1\_vacc\_effective: Ordinal variable
* opinion\_h1n1\_risk: Ordinal variable
* opinion\_h1n1\_sick\_from\_vacc: Ordinal variable
* opinion\_seas\_vacc\_effective: Ordinal variable
* opinion\_seas\_risk: Ordinal variable
* opinion\_seas\_sick\_from\_vacc: Ordinal variable
* household\_adults: Discrete numerical variable
* household\_children: Discrete numerical variable

Note: Ordinal variables have a natural ordering, but the intervals between the categories may not be equal.
